Housekeeping genes encode proteins involved in universally important processes such as transcription, translation, and glycolysis. Because these genes appear to be expressed in all cells at constant levels, the expression of housekeeping genes is often used as a control when comparing how the expression of other genes varies under different conditions.

Researchers studying the effect of pesticides on declining bee populations wanted to determine whether the expression of four housekeeping genes (<math alttext="G A P D H" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>G</mi><mi>A</mi><mi>P</mi><mi>D</mi><mi>H</mi></math>, <math alttext="R P L 32" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>R</mi><mi>P</mi><mi>L</mi><mn mathvariant="italic">32</mn></math>, <math alttext="R P S 5" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>R</mi><mi>P</mi><mi>S</mi><mn mathvariant="italic">5</mn></math>, and <math display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>T</mi><mi>B</mi><mi>P</mi><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">‐</mo><mi>A</mi><mi>F</mi></math>) was in fact constant in bees across different variables. The researchers collected samples of <math alttext="m R N A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>mRNA</mi></math> for each of the four genes and compared how their expression varied across the developmental stage of the bee, the sex of the bee, and the cell type from which the sample was taken. The <math alttext="m R N A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>mRNA</mi></math> from the samples was reverse transcribed to produce <math alttext="D N A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>DNA</mi></math> copies of each gene. <math alttext="P C R" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>PCR</mi></math> was then used to amplify the <math alttext="D N A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>DNA</mi></math>, and the <math alttext="C q" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>Cq</mi></math> value was determined. The <math alttext="C q" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>Cq</mi></math> value is the number of <math alttext="P C R" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>PCR</mi></math> cycles needed to produce a specified number of <math alttext="D N A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>DNA</mi></math> copies. A high <math alttext="C q" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>Cq</mi></math> value for a sample indicates the gene was expressed at a low level.

To analyze whether any of the examined variables affected expression of the housekeeping genes, researchers examined the range of <math alttext="C q" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>Cq</mi></math> values for each gene in response to each variable. Genes with a wide range of <math alttext="C q" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>Cq</mi></math> values were determined to be affected by the variable, while genes with a narrow range of <math alttext="C q" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>Cq</mi></math> values were determined to be unaffected by the variable.

Figure 1. The effect of developmental stage, sex, and cell type on the <math alttext="C q" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>Cq</mtext></math> value of four housekeeping genes

(a) Based on the data in Figure 1, identify the gene that had the lowest median <math alttext="C q" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>Cq</mi></math> value when bees of different developmental stages were compared.
